website_summaries.verdict: The Arlo Go is a solid camera, but Netgear's pay-by-alert pricing plan is a bad deal, so I'd opt for an AT&T or Verizon plan instead.
pros: Netgear's $400 Arlo Go camera works over LTE, rather than Wi-Fi, so you don't have to worry about a spotty wireless connection
It comes with 7 days of free video clip cloud storage
The rechargeable battery lasts for weeks
cons: The motion sensor is adjustable, but overly sensitive -- and Netgear's cellular provider plan is based on the number of alerts you receive
I easily burned through dozens of notifications in an hour or two (and so will you)
The base always feels like it's going to fall off

customer_reviews.title: Can't use with echo show cause of data
customer_reviews.text: The data plan is the most ridiculous scam I've ever seen. First purchased the $49 annual plan and when viewing the camera on an echo show it used up the entire 15 minutes of video. With no motion detection at all. Using it on an Echo Show is simply a live view but yet it uses up all your data plan. Makes no sense at all. I called support, anytime you view your camera its using your data. Nowhere does it actually tell you this. So I just paid $49 to view my camera live for 15 minutes....That has to be the dumbest thing ive heard when it comes to data usage and cameras.
customer_reviews.author: Digiherd

customer_reviews.title: Falsely advertised. These cameras do not provide streaming service ...

customer_reviews.title: Bait and switch and do not buy !!!!
customer_reviews.text: This system is a blatant bait and switch. Only works with Arlo wireless. The rates for the network are truly horrendous and an egregious act of greed. But wait, that's not the wireless plan, only the video plan. How about give us the entire thing for one price and explain what the he'll we are buying ? My farm is now unprotected because its rural and this was my only solution.I'm sending this crap back. Lesson learned people. Always save your boxes !
